content.description:
ANNUAL REVENUES AND EXPENDITURES OF THE AFRICAN FRENCH COLONY OF TOGO, 1938

(in French francs) RevenuesDirect taxes on the people7,933,000Taxes on domestic production and imports22,870,000Revenue from postal service and telegraph1,130,000Funds from the French colonial budget8,744,000Other income3,380,000TOTAL44,057,000ExpendituresColonial official salaries and other expenses17,600,000Public works, communication and infrastructure4,885,000Sleeping sickness-related personnel and other medical costs2,700,000Other expenditures15,259,000TOTAL40,444,000

The figures are from a report of the Togo colonial government to the Ministry of Colonies in Paris.
content.question: Which of the following pieces of data from the table most directly contradicts the claims of European imperial powers that colonies existed for the benefit of the colonized?

choices.label: Colonized peoples were expected to pay taxes to support the colonial government.
Expenditures on administrative salaries were far greater than what was spent on public works and infrastructure.
The colonial government received income from the postal system and from telegraph services.
A significant portion of the colonial budget was provided by the French government.

content.answer: Expenditures on administrative salaries were far greater than what was spent on public works and infrastructure.
